We cannot allow politics to prevent progress in reforming our immigration system, and thatâ€™s why a bipartisan effort is the only way forward if weâ€™re going to find a permanent solution to fixing our immigration system and helping those families at the border.

That means more resources to process asylum claims more efficiently, more immigration judges & social workers, & investment in border security to stop cartels from taking advantage of our immigration system.

If weâ€™re going to fix our broken immigration system, we need a comprehensive solution that ensures both a fair pathway to legal citizenship for immigrants and resources for border security and enforcement.

It is clear that we have not invested enough in the security of our border or the safety of those legally trying to immigrate to our country. I saw firsthand the challenges facing Customs and Border Protection Officers who donâ€™t have the resources they need to do their jobs.
I saw people seeking asylum in long lines, often up to 15 days, and were waiting desperately because there werenâ€™t enough resources to process their claims efficiently.

The people I met in custody put themselves at incredible risk to escape violence, arenâ€™t sure what their future holds, & are being held in poor conditions. Yet, I could still see hope in their eyes. It made me understand more than ever we must come together to find a solution.
I came away from my trip to the border acutely aware of how broken our immigration policy is. I also came away with a commitment to be part of the answer to fix our broken immigration system.
(Thread) My Visit to the Border in McAllen, TX, and the solutions we need to fix our immigration system:

UPDATE FROM THE #BORDER:

Ports of entry are so backed up. Clearly not putting enough resources toward processing asylum claims.

Instead of waiting in long lines, families risk crossing the Rio Grande here, 100s of ft wide. Here see a little girl's hat in mud near the riverbank. pic.twitter.com/1j9xlonJyd

UPDATE FROM THE BORDER:

There's not enough resources here for border officers to process/care for people & families.

People legally seeking asylum waiting in long lines (up to 15 days) just to get through ports of entry.

The system is clearly broken.

More updates coming.
